title: Improper filtering of classes used in codeblocks in Markdown

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Redcarpet just uses the name of the language as the classname of the element. So if the classnames are of significance to the site, one can break the site using this. For instance, this report disables the topbar, and can trigger the user into opening a popup. Proof of concept:

```js-topbar
i eat the topbar
```
```js-share-link
i open a popup
```

activities.message: I think that would be a possible solution. Another solution would be to namespace languages, if it's 'language-ruby' instead of 'ruby' you won't have this problem. The latter would be a change your markdown parser couldn't do without breaking for all its users. It could add an option to prefix the language though (but don't know how this would work with your syntax highlighting code)

@mattr and robin, to see the vulnerability, please choose 'show raw' on my original report. We fixed this both by prepending the language with 'language-', and by whitelisting the allowed languages.

I'm not sure what the best solution for RedCarpet itself is. A good middle ground might be an optional prefix, and accepting only word characters for languages.

But there seems to be an explicit option to allow spaces, which seems strange to me (when it is then converted to classnames, where spaces are seperators), so I don't know if there's some use of the language which I'm not aware of.

activities.message:
Hi everyone!

Sorry for the time it took to give you an answer. This is an interesting problem. I don't know what'd be the best solution.

We can't create a white-list of allowed languages or simply allow words as this can't met all possibilities plus people are relying on things like `html+erb` or `erb?parent=html` with Rouge.

Maybe we should just remove this class by default as we can override the `block_code` callback easily and people often override it to parse the code with Rouge or Pygments but I'm wondering if this would be a breaking change. I don't want to provide any new option though.

@mattr- : What do you think ?

> But there seems to be an explicit option to allow spaces

About which option are you talking please ? Normally if the first line contains a space, it is considered as code and not any language.

Thanks for getting in touch with us guys!

activities.message:
Sorry for so being long to answer here!

> If spaces wouldn't be supported the problem would be way smaller

I'm not sure to understand where do you use spaces. As I said earlier, when creating a code block, if what should be the language contains a space, this is considered as plain code. Could you show me an example please ?

To mitigate the problem, a good solution here could be to write a kind of "security guide" to give the most common caveats and gotchas.

We already have several security issues that are open and we have to choose between the "full-feature" path and "security" one but we need to be backward compatible as well. Maybe we will be secure by default in 4.0 but for now, we will need to stick with this behavior I think.

Feel free to give your thoughts ; thanks for bringing this discussion here guys!

activities.message: I think having some guide would be a good solution. I think you might want to have a generic "I want to use this with user input". Of course, not all your users have this problem (if it's only used for blogposts for instance). Maybe it would be even better to have a safe default, though I'm not sure if that should be considered your responsibility.
